title: Cannon and marble - energy of marble only

content.question: This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes) Students launch identical marbles of mass <math alttext="lowercase m sub lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> horizontally from a toy cannon of varying mass <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is always greater than <math alttext="lowercase m sub lowercase m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown above. The students can attach weights to the cannon to change <math alttext="uppercase M sub C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Each time a marble is launched, the cannon slides backward before coming to rest. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the cannon and the ground is <math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu). For each launch, the students vary the mass of the cannon and launch a marble with the same speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> relative to the ground. The students record the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward. (a) Without manipulating equations, explain how the distance <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward changes, if at all, when marbles are launched from more massive cannons.

(b) Students find the following equation on the Internet to describe the distance <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that the cannon slides backward: <math alttext="x equals, the fraction with numerator lowercase m sub lowercase m, end sub, squared, times v squared, and denominator 2 g, times mu, times uppercase M sub C, end sub, squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>g</mi><mi>μ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Whether or not the equation is correct, is it consistent with your prediction in part (a)? Briefly justify your answer.

(c) If constant horizontal forces were exerted over the same distance on the cannon and on the marble after the launch, which object would require a force with a greater magnitude to completely stop it? Without manipulating or referencing equations, briefly explain your reasoning.

(d) Students correctly derive the following equation relating the force <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> exerted on an object initially at rest over a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the mass <math alttext="lowercase m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the object, and the final momentum <math alttext="p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the object: <math alttext="F equals, the fraction with numerator p squared, and denominator 2 times lowercase m, times d, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is this equation consistent with your description in part (c)? Justify your answer.

Students then discuss the mechanical energy of the marble after it has been launched by the cannon but before it reaches the ground. Both students agree that air resistance is negligible and make the following claims.Student 1: The mechanical energy of the marble is constant. There are no external forces exerted on the marble, so its energy does not change.Student 2: The mechanical energy decreases as the marble falls. This happens because the gravitational force is doing work on the marble.(e) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(f) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 1’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”
(g) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are correct, if either? If neither phrase is correct, write “none.”
(h) Which underlined phrase or phrases in student 2’s statement are incorrect, if either? If neither phrase is incorrect, write “none.”

The graph above shows the horizontal component of the velocity of the marble (dashed line) and the cannon (solid line) relative to the ground. Explain your reasoning.
